lead_paragraph: Sensor data made public by a respected aviation journal indicates rapid and escalating failures in the plane’s flight control system.

byline.contributor: Kareem Fahim reported from Cairo, Marc Santora from New York and Nicola Clark from Paris. Reporting was contributed by Nour Youssef from Cairo; Kenneth Chang from New York; Dimitris Bounias from Athens; Ben Hubbard from Beirut, Lebanon; and Dan Bilefsky from London.
byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM, MARC SANTORA and NICOLA CLARK

headline.print_headline: Jet Data Points to Swift Havoc, but Not Cause
headline.main: Data Points to Rapid Loss of Control Aboard EgyptAir Jet

snippet: Sensor data made public by a respected aviation journal indicates rapid and escalating failures in the plane’s flight control system.
abstract: Sensor data from EgyptAir Flight 804 reveals rapid loss of control and computer-system failures in seconds before plane was lost from radar, but what caused plane to go down remains unknown; rescue teams say that have found scant amounts of debris and human remains in Mediterranean Sea.
